flow.context: David Fischbach is CEO/Owner of Beachfront Only Vacation Rentals — 77-85+ oceanfront-only properties in North County San Diego (Oceanside, Carlsbad, Encinitas), operating since 2000. Retired anesthesiologist who served on the Escapia and VRBO boards, so he is deeply plugged into VR industry tech and distribution. The company runs in-house cleaning staff plus dedicated turnover specialists who inspect after every single stay — they already believe in a verification layer, but it is fully manual and labor-intensive on tight same-day turns (10 AM checkout, 4 PM check-in). Tech stack: Track (PMS + guest/owner portals), UpKeep (CMMS), branded guest app with keyless entry. Oceanside just capped non-hosted STR permits at 480 with 455 already taken, and Fischbach has drawn neighborhood and press scrutiny — preventable guest complaints carry outsized regulatory and reputational risk. Sam's SoCal roots and surfing connect naturally to Oceanside beach culture, and the company has no known photo/ops automation platform — RapidEye fills a clear gap on top of their existing inspection workflow.

opener.label: OPENER
opener.say: Hey David — I actually grew up in LA and I spend a good amount of time down in Oceanside surfing. I work with a few property managers in the vacation rental space on their inspection workflows. It's Sam Parks with RapidEye. Have you heard my name tossed around at all?
opener.note: Feet-up energy. You're a SoCal surfer who happens to work in his industry — not a telemarketer. Smile through the phone. Pause after 'tossed around' and let him answer.

heard_yes.label: HEARD YES
heard_yes.say: Oh nice — well normally we'd be working with someone like you. What'd you hear?
heard_yes.note: Rare but great. Let him talk. Whatever he says, bridge into discovery. Don't correct or over-explain anything.

heard_no.label: HEARD NO
heard_no.say: Ha — I guess I'm not as popular as I thought. Well the reason for my call is —
heard_no.note: Lighten the moment, then go straight into the pain trigger with no pause. This is a bridge line, not a stopping point.

bad_timing.label: BAD TIMING
bad_timing.say: Totally hear you — would it be a terrible idea if I tried you again tomorrow or later this week?
bad_timing.note: Respect the timing. Get a specific callback window if you can. Do not pitch.

reschedule.label: RESCHEDULE LOCKED
reschedule.say: Perfect — I'll try you then. Appreciate it, David.
reschedule.note: Write down the exact day and time. Set a reminder. Don't sneak in a pitch. Clean exit.

permission_fallback.label: PERMISSION FALLBACK
permission_fallback.say: Yeah totally — I mean, it is a cold call. Can I get 30 seconds to tell you why I reached out, and you can totally hang up on me if it's not a fit?
permission_fallback.note: Say it with a smile. The radical honesty disarms. Most people give you the 30 seconds out of curiosity.

permission_rejected.label: PERMISSION REJECTED
permission_rejected.say: Shoot, totally my bad. Just so nobody from my team bugs you again — is it that I caught you at a horrible time, or is it that you already know what we do and this just isn't interesting?
permission_rejected.note: You're diagnosing, not pushing. If it's timing, get a callback. If it's genuine disinterest, end clean and add to a drip sequence.

pain_trigger.label: PAIN TRIGGER
pain_trigger.say: So I work with another property manager running about 80 oceanfront units — honestly, pretty similar setup to yours. They had turnover specialists inspecting every property after every stay, which is better than most operators I talk to. But they were still getting hit with stuff nobody caught on tight same-day turns. You know how it goes — 10 AM checkout, cleaners come through, inspector does their walkthrough, but they're rushing because check-in's at four and there are three more units to hit. A scratch on a countertop, a missing remote, a stain under the couch cushion — stuff slips. Guest checks in, finds something off, and now you've got a one-star review or an owner calling asking what happened.
pain_trigger.note: PAUSE HERE. Let the silence sit. The 10 AM / 4 PM times are HIS actual check-in/check-out schedule. The 'turnover specialists' language mirrors his own website copy. He should feel like you're describing his Tuesday. Wait for his reaction before continuing.

branches.label: Reacts to the pain / agrees / 'yeah, that happens'
We already have a process for that
You should talk to someone else on my team

solution_bridge.label: SOLUTION + CTA
solution_bridge.say: We built an AI that plugs into the photos your team's already taking during turnovers and catches the stuff human eyes miss — damage, missing items, staging issues — without any workflow change on your end. Would you be open to taking a look when I'm not cold calling you out of the blue?
solution_bridge.note: One breath. One sentence on the solution. Then the low-friction CTA. Stop talking and let him respond. Do not add features or benefits.

warm_response.label: THEY'RE WARM — STOP PITCHING
warm_response.say: Yeah, happy to dig in. Before I do though — what does your inspection process actually look like right now? I know you've got the turnover specialist layer after every stay, but I'm curious how that works day-to-day across 80-something units.
warm_response.note: He's warm. STOP SELLING. Ask questions. You already know about the turnover specialists — showing homework builds credibility. Let him explain the gaps himself. He's the CEO so he may describe it high-level or delegate you to Peter or Iryna.

branches.label: Asks what RapidEye actually does first

discovery_process.label: DISCOVERY — CURRENT PROCESS
discovery_process.say: That's really helpful. So when your turnover specialists go through a unit after the cleaners — are they taking photos as part of that, or is it more of a visual checklist?
discovery_process.note: You're establishing whether photos are already in the workflow. If yes, RapidEye plugs right in with zero friction. If no, you position the video walkthrough option. Either answer is good.

branches.label: Not sure — need to check with my team

discovery_deep.label: DISCOVERY — DIG DEEPER
discovery_deep.say: Got it. And when something does slip through — a guest reports damage or something's missing — how does that flow back? Is that running through Track or is it more ad hoc?
discovery_deep.note: You're showing you know they use Track without being weird about it. This uncovers pain around issue resolution speed. If he's surprised you know about Track, stay casual — 'I did a little homework before calling.'

homework_acknowledge.label: ACKNOWLEDGE HOMEWORK
homework_acknowledge.say: Ha — yeah, I did a little homework before calling. Figured if I'm gonna take 60 seconds of your time I should at least know what I'm talking about.
homework_acknowledge.note: Keep it light. CEOs respect preparation. Don't over-explain your sources. Pivot back to discovery or solution.

discovery_photos_yes.label: PHOTOS ALREADY IN WORKFLOW
discovery_photos_yes.say: Perfect — that's actually the ideal setup for what we do. We plug into those exact photos your team's already capturing and run them through our AI. It flags damage, missing items, staging issues — things that are easy to miss when you're moving fast between units. No workflow change on your team's end at all. Would it make sense to show you what that looks like on one of your actual properties?
discovery_photos_yes.note: This is the money path. Photos already exist. RapidEye is purely additive. Push for the meeting now.

discovery_photos_no.label: NO PHOTOS IN CURRENT WORKFLOW
discovery_photos_no.say: Makes sense — a lot of teams do it that way. The challenge we keep hearing is that without photos, when a guest claims damage that was already there, it turns into a he-said-she-said. No documentation to protect you or the owner. One option is we set up a quick video walkthrough — takes your inspector maybe two extra minutes — and our AI analyzes that instead. Catches the same stuff. Would that be worth looking at?
discovery_photos_no.note: Don't make him feel behind. Reframe as protection and documentation. The video walkthrough is RapidEye's second workflow and requires minimal behavior change.

solution_line.label: ONE-SENTENCE SOLUTION
solution_line.say: So in a nutshell — we built an AI that plugs into the turnover photos your team's already taking, analyzes them automatically, and generates inspection reports that catch damage, missing items, and staging issues your specialists might miss when they're moving fast. It works alongside Track so there's no new system to learn.
solution_line.note: One breath. Then STOP. Let him react. Don't add features. The Track mention is critical — it tells him this isn't a rip-and-replace, it layers on top of what he already has.

branches.label: That's interesting / how does it work?

cta_meeting.label: ASK FOR THE MEETING
cta_meeting.say: I'd love to walk you through it properly — and honestly, even if it's not a fit, I can show you what a couple other PM companies in San Diego are doing with their turnover photos right now. Worst case you steal some ideas and we part as friends. Would you be open to 20 minutes this week or next?
cta_meeting.note: Low friction. The 'steal some ideas' line gives him a reason to say yes even if he's skeptical. Push for a specific day and time.

branches.label: Have someone else look at it

book_meeting.label: BOOK THE MEETING
book_meeting.say: Awesome. I've got next Tuesday and Thursday pulled up — does morning or afternoon work better for you?
book_meeting.note: Offer two days. Let him pick AM or PM. Lock the exact time. Send the calendar invite WHILE on the phone. Once it's booked, STOP SELLING.

meeting_booked.label: MEETING LOCKED
meeting_booked.say: Perfect — I'll send over the invite right now so it's on your calendar. Really appreciate you taking my call, David. Talk soon.
meeting_booked.note: Send the invite immediately. Stop talking. Don't re-pitch. Don't add 'one more thing.' Clean exit. Win.

send_email_with_times.label: SEND EMAIL WITH TIMES
send_email_with_times.say: Totally fair. I'll shoot you an email with a couple time options. What's the best email — is it david_fischbach at beachfrontonly?
send_email_with_times.note: Confirm the email address. The format is based on SignalHire's reported pattern. If he corrects it, write down the real one. Include 2-3 specific time slots in the email and follow up in 48 hours.

objection_have_process.label: OBJECTION — ALREADY HAVE A PROCESS
objection_have_process.say: That makes total sense — with 80-something properties you'd have to have something solid in place. And honestly, the fact that you've got dedicated turnover specialists inspecting after every stay puts you ahead of 90 percent of operators I talk to.
objection_have_process.note: AGREE first. Validate his process. He's proud of the turnover specialist layer — do not undermine it. Then move to the split.

split_have_process.label: SPLIT — HAVE A PROCESS
split_have_process.say: Just so I'm not wasting your time — is it that your inspectors are catching everything and you're not seeing slip-throughs, or is it more that changing anything in the middle of the season would be a headache?
split_have_process.note: This split separates 'we're perfect' from 'change is hard.' Almost nobody claims zero slip-throughs with a straight face. Listen for which side he leans toward.

turnover_reframe.label: REFRAME — AUGMENT DON'T REPLACE
turnover_reframe.say: Yeah, that's exactly what we hear. And look — your turnover specialists are great at catching the big stuff. But when they're rushing between units on a Saturday turn, the AI catches the things the human eye skips. A pillow off the couch, a scratch on the countertop, a missing remote. It's not replacing your people — it's backing them up. The companies I work with actually say their inspectors got better once they knew the AI was double-checking behind them.
turnover_reframe.note: This is the key reframe for Beachfront Only. They BELIEVE in verification. RapidEye is a second layer of verification on top of the one they already have. Never position as replacement — always position as backup and quality assurance.

branches.label: That makes sense / tell me more

no_switch_needed.label: NO SWITCH NEEDED
no_switch_needed.say: That's the thing — there's actually no switch. Your team keeps doing exactly what they're doing today. If they're already taking photos during inspections, we just analyze those same photos. Nothing changes for your cleaners or your turnover specialists. It sits on top of what you already have.
no_switch_needed.note: Remove the friction objection entirely. This is additive, not disruptive. Then push for the meeting.

objection_not_interested.label: OBJECTION — NOT INTERESTED
objection_not_interested.say: I totally get it. I should've assumed you'd be all set — otherwise you probably would've reached out to us.
objection_not_interested.note: Agree completely. Don't push back. Let the silence work for a beat. Then move to the split.

split_not_interested.label: SPLIT — NOT INTERESTED
split_not_interested.say: Just so no one from my team cold calls you again — is it that turnover quality isn't really a problem you're focused on right now, or is it more that you just hate cold calls?
split_not_interested.note: The 'hate cold calls' line usually gets a laugh or at least a softer response. If it's timing, pivot to what IS on his mind. If it's the interruption, offer to reconnect differently.

branches.label: Not focused on this right now
Ha — I do hate cold calls

objection_no_budget.label: OBJECTION — NO BUDGET
objection_no_budget.say: Totally get it. Nowadays it's harder to keep a tool, let alone buy something new — especially with everything going on in Oceanside right now with the STR regulations.
objection_no_budget.note: Agree AND show you know his world. The Oceanside regulatory reference signals you understand his operating environment without being preachy about it.

split_no_budget.label: SPLIT — NO BUDGET
split_no_budget.say: Just so I know — is it that budget for this kind of thing is completely locked for the year, or is it more about timing and having too many other priorities right now?
split_no_budget.note: For a CEO/Owner of a private company, approval chains aren't the issue — timing and priority ranking usually are. Listen for what IS getting budget, because that tells you what he values.

branches.label: Budget is locked / not this year
It's more about timing and priorities
Opens up about what he IS spending on

discovery_priorities.label: DISCOVERY — PRIORITIES
discovery_priorities.say: Makes total sense. What's the biggest thing on your plate heading into peak season?
discovery_priorities.note: Let him talk. Whatever he says, listen for ops pain you can connect back to RapidEye. Regulatory compliance, staffing churn, owner retention, scaling — they all connect to inspection quality.

connect_to_rapideye.label: CONNECT BACK TO RAPIDEYE
connect_to_rapideye.say: That's actually exactly where this fits in. The PMs I work with dealing with the same thing — whether it's losing good inspectors or trying to onboard new units fast — they use the AI as a backstop so they're not totally dependent on any one person's eyes catching everything. Takes the pressure off your team. Would it be worth 20 minutes to see if it could help?
connect_to_rapideye.note: Connect his stated priority back to what RapidEye solves. If the connection feels forced, go to sell_test_drive instead. Don't stretch.

regulatory_hook.label: REGULATORY PRESSURE HOOK
regulatory_hook.say: One thing I'll mention — I know Oceanside just capped STR permits at 480 and you're basically at the limit. The operators I talk to in regulated markets like that say the thing keeping them up at night is a preventable guest complaint that spirals into a neighbor issue that spirals into a city council conversation. The AI catches stuff before the guest ever sees it — that alone might be worth a look.
regulatory_hook.note: This is your ace for David specifically. He's under documented regulatory and neighborhood scrutiny. State the facts calmly and let him connect the dots. If he gets defensive about the regulations, back off IMMEDIATELY — this is a sensitive topic for him given the press coverage.

soften_regulatory.label: SOFTEN REGULATORY ANGLE
soften_regulatory.say: Totally — didn't mean to poke at a sore spot. I just know operators in your position are usually thinking two steps ahead on that stuff. Either way, the tool's useful whether it's for compliance or just catching a $500 damage claim before the next guest checks in.
soften_regulatory.note: Back off fast. Don't push the regulatory angle if he bristles — the San Diego Reader articles show this is contentious for him personally. Redirect to the simpler damage-prevention value prop.

sell_test_drive.label: SELL THE TEST DRIVE
sell_test_drive.say: Look — you're probably not buying anything from a cold call today, and I totally respect that. But when you do look at this stuff down the line, the people who move fastest are the ones who already know what's out there. If nothing else, I can show you what a couple other PM companies right here in San Diego are doing with their turnover photos. Worst case you steal a few ideas and we part as friends. Worth 20 minutes?
sell_test_drive.note: This is the 'future value' close. You're not asking him to buy. You're asking him to be informed. The 'right here in San Diego' competitor reference creates subtle urgency without naming names.

send_email.label: SEND ME AN EMAIL
send_email.say: Totally fair. One question before I do — what would be most relevant to include so it doesn't just end up in the pile? Are you more interested in how it works alongside Track, what the ROI looks like for a portfolio your size, or just a quick demo video?
send_email.note: Don't just agree and hang up. This question does two things: keeps him engaged and tells you what he actually cares about so the email is targeted. Mentioning Track shows competence.

send_email_confirm.label: CONFIRM EMAIL AND FOLLOW-UP
send_email_confirm.say: Got it — I'll keep it short and specific. Is david_fischbach at beachfrontonly the best address? And I'll drop a couple time options in there in case you want to hop on a quick call after you've looked at it.
send_email_confirm.note: Confirm the email. Embed 2-3 specific meeting times in the email to create a natural path to a call. Follow up in 48-72 hours if no response.

end_graceful_email.label: END — EMAIL CONFIRMED
end_graceful_email.say: Perfect — you'll have it in the next hour. Appreciate your time, David.
end_graceful_email.note: Send the email within 60 minutes while the call is fresh. Personalize it based on whatever he said. Follow up by phone in 3 days.

referral_ask.label: REFERRAL — WHO OWNS THIS?
referral_ask.say: Totally makes sense — you've got bigger fish to fry. Who on your team would be the best person to look at something like this? I know you've got Peter running maintenance and ops — would it be him, or is there someone else who owns the inspection workflow?
referral_ask.note: Dropping Peter Rodriguez's name shows you've done serious homework and makes it easy for David to confirm or redirect. He may mention Iryna Djomins (Housekeeping Manager), Adele Fischbach, or Adam Fischbach. Take whatever name he gives.

referral_get_intro.label: GET THE WARM INTRO
referral_get_intro.say: Perfect. Would you be open to shooting them a quick heads-up that I'll reach out? That way it's not a totally cold call on their end either. I'll put something tailored together so it actually lands.
referral_get_intro.note: A warm intro from the CEO is gold. If he won't formally intro you, ask for the best way to reach that person directly. Write down everything — name, number, email, best time.

referral_confirm.label: CONFIRM REFERRAL DETAILS
referral_confirm.say: Appreciate that. What's the best way to reach them — do they have a direct line or should I go through the main office?
referral_confirm.note: Get direct contact info. If he only gives a name, you can try the main line at 760-712-4533 or guess the email pattern firstName_lastName@beachfrontonly.com. Confirm spelling of any unfamiliar names.

end_graceful_referral.label: END — REFERRAL SECURED
end_graceful_referral.say: Really appreciate your time, David. I'll reach out to them this week and mention you pointed me their way. And if you ever want to see it yourself, I'm easy to find. Enjoy the waves out there.
end_graceful_referral.note: Light personal close tying back to the surfing opener. Follow up with the referral within 24 hours and lead with David's name. Send David a short thank-you email too.

gatekeeper.label: GATEKEEPER — SLIDE BY
gatekeeper.say: Hey — could you get me through to David? It's Sam.
gatekeeper.note: First name only for both of you. No company name. No pitch. Sound like you know him and expect to be put through. If they ask questions, move to the next level.

gatekeeper_context.label: GATEKEEPER — ADD CONTEXT
gatekeeper_context.say: Yeah — I work with a few other property managers in North County San Diego. Would you mind letting him know it's Sam Parks?
gatekeeper_context.note: Geographic specificity signals legitimacy. 'North County San Diego' is exactly where they operate. Don't pitch RapidEye. Don't explain what you sell. If they push harder, go to social proof.

gatekeeper_social_proof.label: GATEKEEPER — SOCIAL PROOF
gatekeeper_social_proof.say: Totally understand. We help a couple other vacation rental companies in San Diego with their inspection workflows — I sent David a note and just wanted to follow up. Would you mind passing along that Sam Parks from RapidEye called?
gatekeeper_social_proof.note: Three doses of info delivered. If they still won't connect you, leave a clean message and try again in 2 days. Ask for a good time to call back.

gatekeeper_voicemail.label: GATEKEEPER — LEAVE MESSAGE
gatekeeper_voicemail.say: No worries at all. When's usually a good time to catch David in? And is this the best number to reach him?
gatekeeper_voicemail.note: Get the callback window and confirm the number. If they offer to take a message, leave: 'Sam Parks, RapidEye. I work with a few property managers in North County — he can reach me at [your cell].' Keep it under 15 seconds.

branches.label: Gives a good time to call back

end_graceful.label: END — GRACEFUL EXIT
end_graceful.say: Totally understand. If anything changes, I'm easy to find. Appreciate your time, David — enjoy the San Diego sunshine.
end_graceful.note: Do not burn the bridge. Keep it light and warm. Add him to a follow-up email sequence: personalized note in 3 days, second touch in 2 weeks. Note what he said so the follow-up isn't generic.
